_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Revision 11 Executive Summary

Sacramento Regional CSD (Regional San), has instituted a Risk Management Program (RMP) for
the Sacramento Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant (SRWTP), as required by Federal Accidental
Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations at 40 CFR Part 68. The RMP identifies the
equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with any Regulated
Substance (RS) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quantities. The program
describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible effects on
employees. The program also describes offsite public and environmental receptors; provides the
results of an offsite consequences analysis, defines a prevention program, emergency response
program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of RS accidental
releases, and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for auditing of program elements and
implementation of mitigation measures. The previous RMP 5 year update was filed in April 2014
with an update submitted in October of 2015 as required by ARP regulations. The program was
edited in June 2017 with the removal and decommissioning of the Sulfur Dioxide covered process.
An update was submitted in September 2017 to reflect the correction to EPA database deregistration 
of all three covered processes when deregistration was requested for the SO2 process. This update is 
to reflect the 5 year PHA Study which was completed in December 2018. 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The SRWTP treats wastewater collected from the City and County of Sacramento, from the Cities of
Folsom, West Sacramento (Yolo County), Elk Grove, Rancho Cordova, and Citrus Heights. It is
located at 8521 Laguna Station Rd., Elk Grove, CA on 900 acres of a 3,400-acre site between
Interstate 5 and Franklin Blvd., south of Meadowview Rd. The remaining 2,500 acres serve as a
buffer between the Plant and nearb

y residential areas. There are approximately 360 full-time
employees at this site and multiple contractors on site for the EchoWater Project. The Plant treats
an average of 145 million gallons (mgd) of wastewater per day. Effective May of 2017, SRWTP transitioned from gaseous sulfur dioxide to liquid sodium bisulfite for de-chlorination. This reduced the SO2 inventory to less than 300 pounds residual in the sulfur dioxide vacuum gas lines (SOV) which will be cleaned and sealed via the SOV Decommissioning Procedure. Effective December 2017, SRWTP transitioned gaseous chlorine to liquid sodium hypochlorite for disinfection. This reduced chlorine inventory to zero pounds and chlorine equipment will be decommissioned via the Chlorine Decommissioning Project. The Plant continues to have methane in quantities greater than the Federal and State threshold quantities.  
Solids removed in the wastewater treatment process are introduced into the anaerobic digesters at
the Plant. Gas consisting of approximately two-thirds methane is produced in the digesters through
anaerobic digestion. The digester gas is scrubbed to remove hydrogen sulfide and other
contaminants, stored in low pressure gas holders, and piped to a cogeneration plant where it is used
to generate electricity and steam. Digester gas that cannot be used by the cogeneration plant is
flared or optionally used as a fuel source for on site boilers. Most methane is consumed shortly after
it is collected; however, the entire potential stored inventory of digester gas in the plant must be
considered for the purpose of comparison with the Federal threshold quantity

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
SRWTP stores and handles methane in a manner that minimizes the probability and severity of accidental releases to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.
To accomplish this goal, the SRWTP has safety information on methane, the process, and RS eq

uipment and procedures; performed and revalidated a structured assessment of hazards of the process and external events which might affect the process. A Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS), an electronic data management system (filenet), and an interim RMP/PSM excel database are used as management tools for the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS
Many steps to prevent releases of methane have been identified and implemented since the original
RMP submittal. These include, among other things, use of a Plant Emergency Trip System (PET) to effectively isolate the system during an emergency which limits the amount of RS that may be released from the gas management area. There are also redundant processes and isolation points in the gas management system, and numerous facility-specific operational procedures for the digester gas systems.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no accidents involving methane at this facility within the past five years resulting in injuries or offsite consequences.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The SRWTP's Emergency Response Programs applicable to methane have been
coordinated with Sacramento County Environmental Management Department, the local agency
responsible for hazardous materials inventory reporting and release response coordination.
Furthermore, the Gas Management emergency response program was revised in 2012-13 in close
coordination with Cosumnes Fire and Sacramento City Fire Hazmat Departments. SRWTP recently (June 2018) revalidated an offsite consequences analysis of defined release scenarios and work is in coordination with Cosumnes Fire and Sacramento City Fire to revalidate Gas Management emergency response procedures. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS
General accidental release prevention programs that have been implemented by the SRWTP are
categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, traini

ng, engineering controls,
and emergency response programs.  These programs were revalidated in June. 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
SRWTP staff continuously strives towards improvements and mitigation measures in the covered
process areas. The Management of Change/Pre-Start Up Safety Review (MOC/PSSR) program has
been updated and is utilized for change approvals prior to implementation. All improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analyses or compliance audits, that have been committed to be completed, have been completed or are in progress. The sulfur dioxide and chlorine process have been eliminated. Planned safety changes include projects such as reevaluation
of digester gas system operation and physical improvements to reduce the likelihood of
gas venting, continuing re-design of all digester overflow systems, and completion of field validation audits for PSI.
